Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Acuity Specialty Products, Inc., a company with a manufacturing plant in Atlanta pleaded guilty to a one-count information charging it with a knowing violation of the Clean Water Act. Per the terms of the plea agreement, a federal judge imposed a sentence of three years of probation and a fine of $3.8 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2007/June/07_enrd_476.html

Description: Zep Inc., located in Atlanta, GA, has agreed to pay $905,000 to resolve alleged violations of the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/0f6ff6f0ae6af20085257d1600665e3b.html
Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2006 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Alameda
Notes: The amount consists of $48,000 to the class representatives, a $275,000 payment under the Private Attorneys General Act and attorney's fees of $1,162,000 awarded by the court. The defense challenged the latter in a case heard by the California Court of Appeal.

Private Litigation Case Title: Aguilar et al v. Zep Inc. et al
Garza v. Brinderson Constructors, Inc. et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/cases/5670782054caf62cc6000006

Description: E&F Environmental Services (and its owner), New England Builders and Contractors, Blackstone Block Architects and TRC Environmental Corp., agreed to a pay up to $340,000 in settlement of allegations they violated the state's clean air law and regulations with unsafe asbestos procedures during the renovation of a public housing facility in Salem. It was also alleged that New England Builders and Contractors and Blackstone Block Architects violated the state's False Claims Act by submitting claims for payment to the Salem Housing Authority certifying that the work was compliant.
Info Source: https://wayback.archive-it.org/1101/20181226161226/https://www.mass.gov/news/four-companies-settle-allegations-of-illegal-asbestos-work-at-salem-public-housing-facility

Description: First Hartford Realty Corporation and its subsidiaries, EH&N Construction Company, FHRC Management Corporation, Rockland Place Apartments, LP, and LTI Environmental Services, Inc. agreed to pay $250,000 civil penalties (with $50,000 suspended) to settle allegations it engaged in or allowed renovation at a housing complex to be conducted without proper asbestos handling, disposal and abatement practices. Asbestos consulting companies Ted Riley & Company, Inc. and TRC Environmental Corp. also paid $10,000 and $25,000 in civil penalties to resolve related allegations.
Info Source: https://www.mass.gov/news/property-development-and-environmental-consulting-companies-settle-allegations-of-illegal
